headline: Covid Induced Layoff
pros:

cons:

4. Company doesn't care about your career. They will hire you for a project and if it fails then there is no back up plan. 
5. Very high attrition. Every other day you see people around you leaving which makes you wonder whats wrong. 
6. Too much randomness at work place. You are uncertain about everything and management expects everything to run smoothly. 
7. Firing cycle happens once every 2 years. Even before Covid there was a firing cycle in dec 2019. People in the company tell you its a regular event at Ola. And the worst part is after a mass layoff they start recruiting in 2 months. (After Ola fired 1400 people in May 2020, they started recruiting again in Aug-Sep 2020)

headline: Poor work culture and management
pros:
1) You will get to work with Few of the great minds in the industry. 
2) Fast Pace Development.
3) Learning (Both tech and personal)
cons:
1) Politics

3) Higher Attrition Rate (In the past 6-7 months the tech team count has been reduced to 50%) So many good people who had worked hard left. The company doesn't value anything but revenue.
4) The product team is not good as it has to be. They just want to release a product no matter the quality and user experience.
5) It was good in the initial days when I joined, but with each passing day they are behaving more like a service-based organisation.
6) I must say that Ola is not an Employee-Friendly organisation. We started working 6 days from Jan 2021 even if there was no new product to be launched. When the country was going through the Covid pandemic, they asked each employee to come to the office and mandatorily between 9:30 and 5:30. No value to the employee only to the business.
7) New people are not joining the company as it has 6 days/week working. 
8) No career growth as the people whom you are reporting don't have enough time because they need to handle a big team (because so many dev managers have already left due to this toxic work culture and now most of the team have common dev managers).

headline: Worst HR out of all organisations
pros: None at all. Absolutely nothing
cons:
Ola has the worst HR possible. I will explain why

1. They unilaterally made a decision to shift all employees from 5 days a week to 6 days without any consultation. Typically, when you are making such a shift you do it gradually by introducing alternate saturdays, or a half-day on the 6th day or even increase the number of annual leaves to compensate.
But no, one fine day the HR head decides to increase your number of working days by 52 days a year.
What more, this decision to make it a 6 days week was in plans for last 3 months or more. Still they hired new employees over the last month by fooling them that its a 5 day week organisation and now they are stuck. Deceit and trickery is the essence here.
2. They have introduced some ultra stupid core collaboration hours concept, where you have to mandatorily report office everyday by 9.30 AM even if you are working till midnight the previous day. Again zero flexibility for the so called 'startup' culture.
3. Even for a 1 day of leave, you have to apply 3 weeks in advance
4. They even have the audacity to mention on their offer letters, that you are expected to work on public holidays
5. No team bonding exercise like offsite, etc ever takes place. An individual at Ola is only expected to work and do nothing else.

headline: Stressful hours with a verbally abusive and unprofessional manager
pros:
It can be a great collaborative experience as there are some amazingly creative designers working in the UX and brand team.

As a global company, Ola can provide a platform to work on problems that will impact users across countries. This also helps in getting a good understanding of different markets and demographics.
cons:
It's sad to say but there is no room for discussing out innovative and creative ideas. Most teams are only aiming to achieve mediocre results. This happens because of the unrealistic deadlines and many times working under stressful hours (midnight and early mornings). 

Another huge let down is that the manager/head of design (in the year 2020) is verbally abusive, unclear in his approach, treats the members of the design team as his college juniors and abuses them verbally in front of any team. His careless and unprofessional attitude has made many leave the company on a day's notice. A whole team of UX researchers (6 members) slowly left the company under his management. There is no UX research team in Ola as of 2020.

People have cried, cribbed and fall sick working till midnight and early mornings. #BurnoutGuaranteed 

Now one might ask, is there so much work and projects going on? The answer is no. Most of the time the designers are forced to work on one of his ideas that he wants to present to the CEO in order to impress him (which by the way is crystal clear that never going to get built). And then the designers also need to find time to complete the actual projects on-time without missing the unrealistic deadlines.

All the designers are merely pushing pixels, day in and day out, and not getting any chance to do some real problem solving or actually using and implementing any of the design methodologies.

Let me be very clear that these practices are discouraged as there is no time to even think about the user. Designers even joke about it whenever they are being forced (due to the deadlines) to ship a feature which they clearly know has usability issues. #RIPUser

headline: OK company with no structure, long working hours and poor perks
pros:
- Good learning curve.  You've got the opportunity to learn a lot on the job.
- Talented peer group. You can find some really talented people from whom you can learn a lot.
- Few really good teams. The good teams that  are  there are really good.  They do cutting-edge work which are at the forefront in any industry.
cons:
- Long working hours. The little good work you're doing will be bogged down by the tons of very poor, tedious work thrust on you.
- Highly political management.  Despite being a start-up promotions and career-growth are highly political and dependent on how much you  bootlick your manager ( which can involve taking up a lot of  poor quality work, toiling away on the weekends unnecessarily).
- Unstructured organization. Despite being around for close to a decade, the org is still majorly unstructured with no clear division of responsibilities and with poor work frequently  being dumped on the ones weak enough to not push back.
- Un-competitive pay. Although the work is above mark standards and the workload is much higher the pay is  still only at average market level or below. This has caused heavy attrition across levels and management does not seem interested in correcting it.
- From 2019, all perks have also been withdrawn. You don't get free lunches and the snacks in the cafeteria have also been scaled back majorly.

headline: A Nightmare of Epic Proportions
pros:
1. The pay package offered on joining meets and often exceeds industry standards.
2. The office is well-designed and has a reasonably well stocked cafeteria.
cons:
1. Disorganised Middle Management:
The middle management is inefficient, clueless, irresponsible, and they seem to get away with barely doing anything. There is absolutely no sense of accountability, nor any desire to push boundaries or be innovative and offer unique solutions. They have no purpose, no direction as to what needs to be done and are so incompetent, it's unbelievable.
2. Work Environment:
The work environment is extremely volatile and no effort seems to be made to rectify it. There is no sense of team effort or ownership and everybody is clearly in it only for themselves. This is not a welcoming, friendly place at all. People are very quick to play the blame game and shift the blame onto someone else at all times. The level of infighting and unprofessionalism on display is overwhelming. Not an hour goes by when you don't see someone shouting at the top of their lungs or backbiting in the cafeteria. Yes, that happens everywhere but it's much more here than it needs to be. There's a huge difference between being cutthroat and being needlessly vicious, and the people in this organisation don't seem to understand that. If you're looking for a place that's challenging and constructive, this is not the place for you.
3. Long Work Hours:
Employees are expected to stick around for 11-14 hours a day at times while the middle management conveniently leaves at 5:00PM on the dot. 
4. HR has no structure or direction:
Much like the rest of the organisation, the HR also seems lost and directionless. The policies in place are hardly understood by them, let alone explained to us, and there is absolutely no clarity provided on any topic because they probably have no clue either.

headline: Horrible Work-life balance
pros: If you are 22/23 and don't mind dedicating your entire life to work for 3-4 works to make good money, then is no better place for that in India. Age & experience are not really a criteria for success, but all depends on how much stress you can bear and for how long.
cons:
Working late and across the weekend is 'expected'. The leadership is perpetually working round the clock, so the 'culture' is to just follow that. If the boss is in office on a Sunday evening taking reviews, his entire team spends previous 36 hours in office prepping for that. 

You might say startups are supposed to be intense, but this is a notch above everything that I, my team mates and my friends at other places have seen/experienced. Ola has a few thousand people now and is not a garage startup anymore - things need to change with time; organisation needs maturity..period. 

Working weekends & late nights is not the core issue but the whole culture around 'expectation' that employees have nothing else going on in their own lives is what ruins the place. An old-ish employee recently left since her boss was not willing to give anymore time off to recuperate from a pretty serious illness. People are made to feel very guilty about taking any time off. Holidays are just a thing on the calendar that nobody cares about - Aug 15 or Ganesh Chathurti was like any other normal weekend with people coming in late and leaving early at 8PM for dinner.

Almost everyone in our team has either worked or has friends in other startups in India - this place seems very different & very intrusive in your life. People leave as soon as they hit a year. Prospective hires just don't accept offers from this place even with better compensation/roles etc
